summary: This document is an email chain from October 31, 2019, between defense attorney Bruce Barket and an Assistant United States Attorney (AUSA) regarding a discovery access issue for their client, Nick Tartaglione. The defense attorney raises concerns that Tartaglione has not had regular access to his discovery materials since October 18th, while the AUSA states arrangements were made for weekend viewing.

persons.name: Bruce Barket
persons.context: Attorney representing Nick Tartaglione, corresponding with a federal prosecutor about his client's access to discovery materials.

persons.name: Nick Tartaglione
persons.context: The individual whose access to legal discovery materials is the subject of the email dispute between his attorney and the prosecutor.

connections.description: Bruce Barket is the legal representative advocating for Nick Tartaglione's access to discovery materials in his criminal case.

events.title: Discovery Taken from Tartaglione
events.description: The date when Nick Tartaglione's discovery materials were reportedly taken from him, leading to the subsequent access dispute.

events.title: Email Dispute Over Discovery Access
events.description: Email correspondence where defense attorney Bruce Barket raises an urgent issue with a federal prosecutor regarding his client Nick Tartaglione's lack of access to discovery since October 18th.

keyFacts: Defense attorney Bruce Barket raised a formal complaint that his client, Nick Tartaglione, had not been permitted to view his discovery materials since they were taken from him on October 18, 2019.

An Assistant United States Attorney from the Southern District of New York stated that arrangements had been made for Tartaglione to view discovery in an attorney conference room the prior weekend and would be made again for the upcoming weekend.
The email chain highlights a procedural dispute within the legal process concerning a defendant's access to evidence in a federal case.
